editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE RURAL HARMONY, BEING AN ORIGINAL COMPOSITION IN THREE and FOUR PARTS. For the USE of SINGING SCHOOLS and MUSICAL SOCIETIES.
BY JACOB KIMBALL, JUN. A. B.

q.l: The man who has not mu≈øic in his ≈øoul,
And is not mov'd by concert of ≈øweet ≈øounds,
The motions of his ≈øpirit are dull as night,
And his affections dark as Erebus.

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p: IN a country where mu≈øic has not yet become a regular profe≈ø≈øion, it cannot be expected that a compo≈øition of this kind can ≈øtand a rigid critici≈øm; but as every attempt to ≈øub≈øerve the intere≈øt, or to encrea≈øe the innocent plea≈øures of the community, de≈øerves public patronage, the author of the following work, without further apology, pre≈øents it to the public eye.

He has aimed at originality in his compo≈øitions, and endeavoured to deviate (as far as he deemed it ju≈øtifiable) from the common ≈øtyle; where he has given into it, he has attempted to improve it by a particular attention to the harmony.

Tho≈øe who have encouraged the work by ≈øub≈øcription, are re≈øpectfully thanked, and are a≈ø≈øured that the utmo≈øt pains have been taken to render the work correct; ≈øuch errors as e≈øcaped ob≈øervation in the execution of it, are noticed in the errata.

The author ≈øincerely wi≈øhes that the purcha≈øers of the work may derive ≈øufficient advantage from it, to compen≈øate them for their expen≈øes; but ≈øhould the rever≈øe be true, he will as ≈øincerely lament that he and his friends have mi≈øtaken his abilities.

div.head: INTRODUCTION to the ART of SINGING.
Of MUSIC in GENERAL.
div.p: "MUSIC con≈øi≈øts in a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of plea≈øing ≈øounds;"‚ÄîAs a Science, it demon≈øtrates and explains their true relation and ju≈øt di≈øpo≈øition;‚Äîas an Art, it teaches their proper expre≈ø≈øion.

All mu≈øick is comprehended in melody and harmony. Melody is a ≈øingle ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of founds; or, in other words, is the air of a piece of mu≈øic. Harmony is the combination of ≈øeveral ≈øounds at the ≈øame time. Modulation is the ju≈øt arrangement of the ≈øounds both of the Melody and Harmony.

The primary and mo≈øt e≈ø≈øential qualities of mu≈øical ≈øounds are, Time and Tune; upon a due attention to the≈øe di≈øtinctions, and their judicious management, depends all the plea≈øing and infinite variety of the mu≈øical art.

div.head: Of the GAMUT, or SCALE of MUSIC.
div.p:
There are but ≈øeven di≈øtinct degrees of ≈øound in the ≈øcale; five of which are called whole, and two are called half, or ≈øemi-tones. Every eighth from any given ≈øound will be the ≈øame, and the degrees of a≈øcent or de≈øcent from it, will be in effect a repetition of the former ≈øounds. The≈øe ≈øeven ≈øounds are repre≈øented on lines and ≈øpaces by the ≈øeven fir≈øt letters of the alphabet; their places on them are as follow:

THE ≈øcale is divided into three parts; each part, con≈øi≈øting of five lines, with their ≈øpaces, and di≈øtingui≈øhed with a cliff, is called a ≈øtave.
The fir≈øt divi≈øion is called the Ba≈øs ≈øtave; its cliff is thus marked ùÑ¢ and is called the F cliff‚Äîit is always placed on the fourth line from the bottom.

The ≈øecond divi≈øion of the ≈øcale is called the Counter ≈øtave;‚Äîits cliff is thus marked ùÑ° and is called the C cliff. It is commonly placed on the middle line of the ≈øtave. This cliff, however, is moveable, and may be placed on either of the five lines or ≈øpaces; that line or ≈øpace which pa≈ø≈øes between the two tran≈øver≈øe ≈øtrokes, will be C, and all the other letters of the ≈øcale will be in regular ≈øucce≈ø≈øion above and below it.
The third and la≈øt divi≈øion of the ≈øcale is called the Treble or Tenor ≈øtave; its cliff is marked thus ùÑû and is called the G cliff; its place is invariably on the ≈øecond line from the bottom.

There are but four names of notes repre≈øenting ≈øounds, viz. Mi, Fa, Sol, La: of which Mi is the principal, and governs all the re≈øt; and when Mi is found, the order of the notes above it will be Fa, Sol, La, Fa, Sol, La; and below Mi, La, Sol, Fa, and then Mi recurs, either way.

It has been before ob≈øerved, that of the ≈øeven degrees of ≈øound in the ≈øcale, two are ≈øemi-tones; their natural places are between B and C, and E and F. Their ≈øituation, however, is often varied by flats and ≈øharps, which tran≈øpo≈øe Mi from B, its natural place; in all which ca≈øes the ≈øemitones will be between Mi and Fa, and La and Fa, as in the natural ≈øcale.

A flat mu≈øt be placed a fourth above, or a fifth below the one la≈øt added; and Mi will be a fourth above, or a fifth below that.‚ÄîA ≈øharp mu≈øt be placed a fifth above, or a fourth below the one la≈øt added‚Äî Mi is always on the letter la≈øt ≈øharped.

div.head: MUSICAL CHARACTERS and TERMS, with their EXPLANATIONS and USES.

div.p: The≈øe three are very important characters in mu≈øic; and their effects and u≈øes ≈øhould be carefully and critically explained to learners by every teacher.

item.p: A trill or ≈øhake is a quick and alternate repetition of the note over which it is placed, and the note immediately above it (from which the trill begins) ≈øo long as the time will allow; thus „Äà‚ô´„Äâ
A trill may be open or clo≈øe; if the note immediately above that to be ≈øhaken be a whole tone from it, it will be an open ≈øhake; if but half a tone, it will be a clo≈øe ≈øhake.
When the note immediately under that to be ≈øhaken is in≈øerted ju≈øt before the conclu≈øion of the trill, it is called a turned ≈øhake.
The trill is a very beautiful grace, but as it is very difficult to be acquired, it may not be ami≈øs to propo≈øe the following ≈øub≈øtitute for it, till it can be perfectly learned, viz.
This manner of performing a trill, if the note be not a long one, and if the note ≈øucceeding it be de≈øcending, produces a very agreeable effect.

Notes of tran≈øition are al≈øo ≈ømall notes added to the regular notes, and u≈øually ≈ølurred to them; the time given to them is commonly taken from the preceding note, and always from the note to which they are tied. Tran≈øition is con≈øidered as a mu≈øical grace, and judicious
performers may introduce it in many places where the notes are not expre≈ø≈øed in the compo≈øition; but young ≈øingers ≈øhould be cautioned again≈øt its two frequent u≈øe; for an un≈økillful introduction of it, in≈øtead of gracing, will have quite a contrary effect upon the mu≈øic; and indeed this, and every other mu≈øical grace, had better be entirely omitted than performed in an irregular manner.

div.p: A variety of other mu≈øical terms might be explained, but as they are not often met within mu≈øic books in this country, it may not be nece≈ø≈øary to in≈øert them.

div.head: Of TIME, and its various MARKS or MODES.
div.p: THERE are three kinds of time made u≈øe of in Mu≈øic, viz. Common Time, Treble Time, and Compound Time.

Common Time is divided into four modes. The fir≈øt mode is called Adagio, and is thus marked ùÑ¥ This mode contains one ≈øemibreve, or the value thereof in other notes or re≈øts in each bar:‚ÄîThe bar is u≈øually performed in the time of four ≈øeconds.

The ≈øecond mode of common time is called Largo, and thus marked
common time (largro) It contains the ≈øame quantity of notes in the bar as the foregoing, but is performed a quarter fa≈øter.

The third mode of common time is called Allegro, and thus marked
common time (allegro) This al≈øo contains the ≈øame notes in a bar as the fir≈øt mode, but the bar is performed in the time of two ≈øeconds.
The fourth mode of common time is marked 2/4 and contains the amount of one minim in the bar:‚Äîit is performed about one quarter fa≈øter than the Allegro mode.

Treble time is divided into three modes. The fir≈øt mode is marked thus 3/2 and contains three minims in a bar, or other notes and re≈øts to that amount. The bar is performed in the time of three ≈øconds.
The ≈øecond mode of treble time is marked thus 3/4 and contains three crotchets or their value in each bar, and is performed about a quarter fa≈øter.
The third mode of treble time is thus marked 3/8 and contains the value of three quavers in a bar: This mode is performed about a quarter fa≈øter than the ≈øecond.
There are many modes of compound time, two of which only ≈øhall be noticed here.
The fir≈øt mode is thus marked 6/4 and contains the value of ≈øix crotchets in a bar. The bar is performed in the time of two ≈øeconds.
The ≈øecond mode is thus marked 6/8 and contains the amount of ≈øix quavers in a bar. It is performed one quarter fafter than the fir≈øt mode.

It may not be un≈øerviceable to ob≈øerve in this place, that the fir≈øt mode of common time is the ≈øtandard with which all other modes are compared, and by which they are regulated. All modes which are marked with figures have a primary reference to this mode, and are derived from it;‚Äîthus, the mark 2/4 denotes that the bar mu≈øt contain two fourths of a bar in the fir≈øt mode of common time, or (which is the ≈øame thing) of a ≈øemibreve; and all other figures di≈øtingui≈øhing different modes may be con≈øidered as fractions of a ≈øemibreve; the under figure expre≈ø≈øing how many parts the ≈øemibreve mu≈øt be divided into, and the upper figure ≈øhewing how many of tho≈øe parts are contained in a bar.

When the modes above explained are thoroughly under≈øtood, a proper attention to the foregoing remarks will enable any one to acquire an idea of all other modes marked with figures, without any further illu≈øtration.

div.head: Of BEATING TIME.
div.p: BEATING time is an artificial way of mea≈øuting the proportionate duration of the notes; the common methods of doing which, are as follow, yiz. For the two fir≈øt modes of common time, which have four beats in a bar, 1≈øt, let the ends of the fingers fall; 2d, the heel of the hand; 3d, rai≈øe the heel of the hand; 4th, throw up the ends of the fingers, and the bar will be fini≈øhed.

For the third and fourth modes of common time, and for the 6/4 and 6/8 modes of compound time, which have only two beats in a bar, 1≈øt, let the hand fall; 2d, rai≈øe it, and the bar will be completed.
For treble time, all the modes of which have three beats in a bar, 1≈øt, let the ends of the fingers fall; 2d, the heel of the hand; 3d, throw up the ends of the fingers, &c.

div.head: EXAMPLES for BEATING TIME.

div.head: Of SYNCOPATION.
div.p: NOTES of Syncopation are ≈øuch as have their ≈øound continued through bars, or are placed out of their natural order in them; very difficult examples of ≈øuch notes may be framed, but when words are applied to them, they induce a forced and vicious pronunciation, and never occur in good vocal mu≈øic; the common in≈øtances are by no means difficult to be executed, and do not merit a particular explanation.

div.head: Of ACCENT.
div.p: ACCENT is a certain modulation or warbling of the ≈øounds, in order to expre≈øs the pa≈ø≈øions naturally with the voice.

Accented parts of the bar are, for common time, the fir≈øt and third parts; for treble time, the fir≈øt part only; for compound time, the fir≈øt and fourth parts of the bar; and emphatical words ≈øhould be ≈øet to tho≈øe parts; but it will often happen, that ≈øuch words will occur in other parts, and the accented parts have words of no empha≈øis; in which ca≈øes, every one mu≈øt feel the propriety of the mu≈øic's bending to the words, and that the general rule for accenting mu≈øt be neglected; and from hence, may be inferred, that the doctrine of accent is de≈øigned more for the u≈øe of the compo≈øer, than of the performer.

div.head: Of the KEYS of MUSIC.
div.p: THERE are but two keys in mu≈øic, viz. 1≈øt, the major or ≈øharp key, and 2d. the minor or flat key. The fir≈øt of the≈øe is adapted to expre≈øs the cheerful pa≈ø≈øions, and the latter is expre≈ø≈øive of the ≈øolemn, the mournful and the pathetic.

The key note is that ≈øound upon which a tune may be ≈øaid to be built:‚ÄîIt is the predominant tone, to which all others have a particular reference; it is commonly the concluding note of the tenor, and always that of the ba≈øs,
In reckoning from the key note, if the ≈øemitones in the octave be between the third and the fourth, and between the ≈øeventh and the eighth, the tune is in the major or ≈øharp key; if they lie between the ≈øecond and third, and between the fifth and ≈øixth, it is in the minor or flat key.
In the natural ≈øcale the key note of the major key, will be C; of the minor it will be A.

C, Major Key. „Äà‚ô´„Äâ
The regular places for the half tones are between B and C, and E and F, an examination of the octave as laid down above, ≈øhews that they lie between the third and fourth, and between the ≈øeventh and eighth, con≈øequently it is in the ≈øharp key, &c.
A, Minor Key. „Äà‚ô´„Äâ An examination of this octave ≈øhews that the ≈øemitones are between the ≈øecond and third, and between the fifth and ≈øixth, of cour≈øe it is the flat key, &c.

No tune can be regularly compo≈øed on any other letter be≈øides C and A, without the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of flats or ≈øharps; but, by a proper placing of them on the lines and ≈øpaces, every ≈øemitone contained in the octave may be made the foundation or key note of a tune: For in ≈øtance, if the letter C be taken for the key note of a tune in the major key, one of the ≈øemitones will be between the ≈øixth and ≈øeventh, whereas it ≈øhould be between the ≈øeventh and eighth; now, by placing a ≈øharp on F, the ≈øound of all the notes on that letter will be a ≈øemitone higher than in the natural ≈øcale, and con≈øequently leave but half a tone between the ≈øeventh and eighth from G; by which mean, G then becomes regularly the key note for a tune in the ≈øharp key.

It would be no difficult ta≈øk to extend this explanation through all the ≈øemitones contained in the octave, but perhaps it may be ≈øufficient for learners to be taught to di≈øtingui≈øh the keys, in the fir≈øt place, by the following rule, viz. if the key note be the Fa immediately above Mi, a third from it will be a major third, and the mu≈øic will be in the ≈øharp key; but if the key note be the La immediately under Mi, a third from it will be a minor third, and the tune will be in the fiat key.
N. B. A. major third contains two whole, or four ≈øemitones. A minor third contains but three ≈øemitones.

div.head: LESSONS for TUNING the VOICE.
div.p: N. B. This le≈ø≈øon ≈øhould be well learned, and the relative di≈øtance of each note from the key note, (as di≈øtingui≈øhed by the figures placed over them) under≈øtood ≈øo as to be ≈øounded readily, before tunes in the major key are attempted.

N. B. This le≈ø≈øon al≈øo ≈øhould be well under≈øtood before tunes in the minor key are attempted. Whichever of the≈øe le≈ø≈øons a teacher chu≈øes his pupils ≈øhould fir≈øt attend to, it is recommended that they be made to practi≈øe upon tunes in the ≈øame key, before they endeavour to acquire a knowledge of the other, &c.

div.head: PARTICULAR OBSERVATIONS.
div.p: IN the following work, when tunes have but three parts, the treble is placed between the tenor and the ba≈øs; when they have four parts, the tenor is placed next to the ba≈øs, the counter next to the tenor, and the treble next to the counter.
Flats, ≈øharps, and naturals, are not con≈øidered as having influence (excepting at the beginning of tunes or ≈øtrains) upon any note but that immediately ≈øucceeding.
The pitch of all the parts ≈øhould be taken from the key note.

div.head: MISCELLANEOUS OBSERVATIONS.
div.p: EVERY per≈øon ≈øhould ≈øing that part to which his voice is be≈øt adapted; to determine which, learners ≈øhould ≈øubmit to the judgment of their teacher.
The tone of the ba≈øs ≈øhould be full and maje≈øtic; of the tenor, bold and manly; of the counter, ≈øoft yet firm; of the treble, ≈ømooth and delicate.
High notes in every part ≈øhould, in general, be ≈øung ≈øofter than the low.

In a company of fingers it would have a good effect for ≈øome of the performers on each part to be ≈øilent when pa≈ø≈øages marked piano, occur; the additional ≈øtrength of their voices in the forte, which generally precedes or ≈øucceeds the piano, would mark the contra≈øt more di≈øtinctly, and give peculiar force and energy to the performance.

The various inflections of voice and tone, which render one air more expre≈ø≈øive of one pa≈ø≈øion than another, cannot be taught by certain and infallible rules; a performer ≈øhould endeavour to form a proper idea of the author's de≈øign in a piece of mu≈øic, and his own judgment and ta≈øte mu≈øt be his principal directors in doing ju≈øtice to it.

A good and graceful manner of ≈øinging is be≈øt acquired by imitoetion. A teacher cannot by precept alone in≈øtruct his pupils in the art of modulating different airs to expre≈øs different pa≈ø≈øions; but by example he can.

Every note of every part of an excellent piece of mu≈øic may be founded, ≈øtrictly ≈øpeaking, right, and the compo≈øition, neverthele≈øs, appear dull and trifling. It is the expre≈ø≈øive manner‚Äîthe realizing the pa≈ø≈øion‚Äîand giving particular empha≈øis to tho≈øe words which contain the force of the ≈øentiment, which give ri≈øe to the inexpre≈ø≈øible delight derived from hearing good mu≈øical performances.

The voice, the looks, the ge≈øtures of the performers, are ≈øeverally nece≈ø≈øary to give mu≈øic its full energy, and are re≈øpectively the ≈øources of plea≈øure or di≈øgu≈øt to the ob≈øerving hearer.

Be≈øides the artificial graces of mu≈øic, ≈øuch as trills, appoggiatura, &c. there are innumerable others which never have been, nor ever can be, defined; but mu≈øt be learned (as was hinted before) by imitation, or ≈øugge≈øted by a di≈øcerning judgment.

Few graces, however, if any, are admi≈ø≈øible in full choru≈ø≈øes, unle≈øs they are expre≈ø≈øed in the compo≈øition; in ≈øtrains of two or three parts, they may be frequently introduced; but ≈øolos are the proper field for their full di≈øplay.

A vulgar, inarticulate pronunciation‚Äîa heavy, lifele≈øs manner‚Äî≈øudden and unmeaning explo≈øions of ≈øound, are totally incon≈øi≈øtent with good ≈øinging; on the other hand, a clear and ≈øpirited tone‚Äîa ju≈øt and accurate pronunciation‚Äîand occa≈øional ≈øwells upon the notes, judiciou≈øly introduced, are di≈øtingui≈øhing characteri≈øtics of an elegant performer.

In good mu≈øic, as well as in good poetry, or in any other ≈øpecies of good writing, there are different ≈øtyles; ≈øome of which, though they may not, at fir≈øt hearing, command a very favourable opinion, upon being often performed, and rendered familiar, will plea≈øe more, and longer, than others which were thought ≈øuperior; hence, the impropriety and inju≈øtice of ha≈øtily rejecting, as worthle≈øs and in≈øignificant, ≈øuch mu≈øic as may be compo≈øed out of the common ≈øtyle.

In compo≈øition, it is an e≈ø≈øential point to adapt the tune to the ≈øubject of the ≈øong. Subjects of penitence, prayer, ≈øorrow, &c. require tunes in the minor key; and tho≈øe of cheerfulne≈øs, joy, thank≈øgiving; &c. the major key; but this rule is often violated; and with the mo≈øt unhappy and ridiculous effect. Can that joy, or prai≈øe, or thank≈øgiving be thought ≈øincere, the expre≈ø≈øion of which is accompanied with ≈øighs, and groans, and tears? Can his ≈øorrow or di≈øtre≈øs appear otherwi≈øe than farcical, who≈øe relation of it is interrupted by ≈øallies of plea≈øantry, and peals of laughter? If this be not an unju≈øt repre≈øentation of the effect of di≈øregarding the foregoing rule, (and it is pre≈øumed it is not) it mu≈øt be con≈øidered not only a tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion again≈øt all mu≈øical propriety, but an outrageous affront to common ≈øen≈øe.

In churches and congregations this rule demands a ≈øtill more particular attention; for an injudicious application of tunes to the p≈øalms or hymns, will make the performance appear a profane burle≈øque upon a very important duty.

A decent and regular demeanor in a band of ≈øingers, adds much to the plea≈øure ari≈øing from their performances; in wor≈øhipping ≈øocieties, a contrary behaviour is altogether inexcu≈øable, and well de≈øerves the cen≈øure of every ≈øober mind; for it argues a total in≈øen≈øibility to tho≈øe ≈øolemn impre≈ø≈øions, which every one ≈øhould feel when in the more immediate pre≈øence of the Supreme Being, and employed in one of the highe≈øt acts of his wor≈øhip.
